title: Descriptive Statistics
text: While descriptive statistics are a foundational concept, they have broad applications across various fields of statistics, regardless of the data background. These statistics are essential for summarizing and organizing data, providing a clearer understanding of central tendencies, variability, and distribution. Key measures such as mean, median, mode, and standard deviation offer fundamental insights into data patterns and behavior. Despite their simplicity, these measures are often overlooked, yet they play a crucial role in data analysis. When properly utilized, descriptive statistics can uncover trends, highlight inconsistencies (outliers), and provide valuable context for decision-making and deeper statistical exploration. They also serve as a fundamental component of Exploratory Data Analysis (EDA), helping analysts identify patterns before applying more complex techniques.

title: Descriptive Statistics
text:
Mean (Average)
The mean, also referred to as the average of data, is calculated by summing all data values in a dataset and dividing by the total number of values. It provides a central value for the data and is widely used due to its simplicity in calculating and interpretation. For example, when analyzing the average income of a population, the mean can highlight general economic trends. However, one of the major implications when using the average of a data set is its sensitivity to extreme values (outliers), which can skew the results and provide a misleading representation of a sample population.

Formulas

Population Mean

In general, the sample mean is calculated more frequently in statistics due to the difficulty of obtaining data for an entire population, and since datasets are usually a sample of any given population.



Interpretation
Interpreting the mean is very simple; a high mean indicates a high central tendency, while a low mean indicates a lower concentration of values, assuming there are no outliers observed in a set of data.

title: Descriptive Statistics
text:
Median
The median is the middle value in a sorted dataset. Unlike the mean, the median is resistant to outliers, making it a better measure of central tendency for skewed data. For instance, in a dataset of home prices, the median provides a more accurate depiction of the typical home cost when a few luxury properties distort the mean.

How to Calculate by Hand
Arrange the data in ascending order.
If the number of observations () is odd, the median is the middle value.
If is even, the median is the average of the two middle values.
In statistical programming, such as R, the median is often favored for skewed datasets or when outliers are present. Many functions within software default to using the median for robust analysis due to its resistance to extreme values.


Interpretation
The median reflects the point at which 50% of the data falls below and 50% falls above, which, while it is like the mean, the median provides the exact middle value of the data, disregarding skews and outliers.

title: Descriptive Statistics
text:
Mode
The mode is the value that appears most frequently in a dataset. It is particularly useful for categorical data, where calculating a mean or median may not be appropriate. For example, in survey results, the mode can identify the most common preference or choice among respondents. This is also the easiest measure to find, as no calculations are required.

Interpretation
A data set can be unimodal (one mode), bimodal (two modes), or multimodal (multiple modes). The mode provides insights into the frequency distribution of the data.

title: Descriptive Statistics
text:
Standard Deviation
The standard deviation measures the dispersion or spread of data around the mean. A small standard deviation indicates that the data points are close to the mean, while a large standard deviation suggests significant variability.

Similarly to the mean, the sample standard deviation is the more common form, as finding the population standard deviation would be extremely difficult due to the sizes of general populations.



Interpretation
A high standard deviation indicates greater variability, which may suggest heterogeneity or diverse elements within a data set. For example, in test scores, a low standard deviation means most students scored similarly, whereas a high standard deviation indicates a wider range of performance levels, which could be due to other existing factors.

title: Descriptive Statistics
text:
Advanced Uses and Interpretation

Comparing Data Sets
Descriptive statistics allow researchers to compare data sets effectively. For instance, comparing the means and standard deviations of two groups can highlight significant differences or similarities.


Identifying Trends
The mean and standard deviation are often used to track trends over time, such as changes in stock prices or population growth.


Understanding Data Distributions
Descriptive measures help identify whether the data follows a normal distribution or exhibits skewness and kurtosis. This understanding is crucial for selecting appropriate statistical tests.


Quality Control
In manufacturing industries, standard deviation is essential for quality control processes, ensuring product consistency.
Descriptive statistics serve as the foundation for understanding and interpreting data in any statistical analysis. The mean, median, mode, and standard deviation provide valuable insights into central tendency and variability, making them indispensable tools for summarizing and analyzing data. By mastering these measures, researchers and analysts can uncover meaningful patterns and trends, enabling informed decision-making across various fields.

title: Introduction to Data Types
text: While working with data, it is important to understand the types of data ou a re working with, as the type often influences analysis and modeling processes. The goal here is to review/introduce different data types, as well as appropriate tests that fit with each type. With that said, there are two main data types: Categorical and Numerical.

title: Introduction to Data Types
text:
Categorical Data (Qualitative):
Categorical data represent characteristics or qualities that are often used to group objects. These values are mostly labels or categories and cannot be measured in a numerical value.

Examples of Categorical Data:
Color: Red, Blue, Green, etc.
City: Philadelphia, New York City, Los Angeles
Blood Type: A, B, AB, O
Looking further into categorical data, there are two types: Nominal Data and Ordinal Data. The sole difference between the two is whether they are ordered, with Nominal data following no order while Ordinal Data is ordered.


Examples of Nominal Data (No Order):
Marital Status: Single, Married, Divorced, Widowed
Eye Color: Brown, Green, Blue, Hazel
Car Brand: Toyota, Subaru, Ford, BMW


Examples of Ordinal Data (With Order):
Education Level: High School, Associate’s Degree, Bachelor’s Degree, Master’s Degree, Ph.D.
Pain Level: Mild, Moderate, Severe
Job Performance: Poor, Average, Good, Excellent

title: Introduction to Data Types
text:
Binary Data
There is also a third type of categorical data, however, is treated as a special case, as it does not fall within the other two types of data. This type is called Binary Data, and it can only take on two possible values, often shown in 0’s and 1’s, which translate to True/False or Yes/No.

Examples of Binary Data:
Light Switch: On (1), Off (0)
Gender: Male (1), Female (0)
Has a Driver’s License: Yes (1), No (0)
Pass/Fail: Pass (1), Fail (0)

title: Introduction to Data Types
text:
Numerical Data (Quantitative):
Numerical Data are values that represent a measurable quantity. These values can be measured or mathematically manipulated.

Examples of Numerical Data:
Age (in years): 25, 40, 60, 84
Income (USD): 35,000, 50,000, 74,000, 102,000
Weight (lbs.): 134, 183.4, 200.5, 230.1
Like Categorical Data, there are also two types of numerical data, these being Discrete and Continuous Data. Discrete Data can only take certain distinct values, typically full integers, and there is no continuity between these values. Continuous data is data that can take any value within a set range.


Examples of Discrete Data:
Number of Children: 0, 1, 2, 3
Number of Pages in a Book: 120, 300, 400, 565
Number of Wins of a Sports Teams: 10, 12, 15, 85


Examples of Continuous Data:
Height (ft.): 5.7, 6.2, 4.11, 7.1
Temperature (F): 76, 85, 43, 19
Time (hours): 3.5, 5, 8.2, 12

title: Introduction to Data Types
text:
Date and Time Data:
These are values that represent points of time or durations. They are often treated slightly differently than categorical and numerical data, but they can still be categorized or measured.

Examples of Time Data:
Date of Birth: August 11, 2003, 08/11/2003
Event Timestamp: 10:32 PM, September 20, 2021
Subscription Duration: 3 months, 6 months, 1 year
Time Spent on Website: 15 minutes, 12 seconds

title: Introduction to Data Types
text:
Statistical Tests for Data Types:
It is important to identify the types of data present, as it acts as a guide to what tests are needed to answer your research questions. In the simplest terms, testing methods can be split up into groups that depend on the combinations of the variable types in the dataset, which can be seen below.

“Why are Data Types Important for Choosing Tests?”
Data types matter in statistical testing because different types of data alter the assumptions, structure, and interpretation of testing and the results that follow. A brief explanation is that numerical data allows for mathematical operations, allowing for the use of tests that require mean and averages, while categorical data relies on tests that measure frequencies or associations. Examples of different tests for each combination of variable types can be found below:


Numerical vs. Numerical:
Pearson Correlation:
Measures the strength and direction of the linear relationship between two continuous variables.
Spearman Rank Correlation:
For non-linear relationships between two continuous variables.
Linear Regression:
To explore a relationship, using one continuous predictor variable on one response variable.


Numerical vs. Categorical (Two Groups):

T-test:
Compares the means for two groups (control vs. treatment).
Can be split into two categories:


Paired T-test:
When two measurements are taken from the same group.


Independent T-test:
For comparing two independent groups.


Mann-Whitney U Test:
Non-parametric test for comparing medians of two independent groups when the data is not normally distributed.



Numerical vs. Categorical (More Than Two Groups):

ANOVA (Analysis of Variance):
Tests if there is a significant difference between the means of three or more independent groups.


Kruskal-Wallis Test:
Non-parametric alternative to ANOVA for comparing medians across multiple groups.


Tukey’s HSD:
For pairwise comparisons after finding significance in ANOVA testing.



Categorical vs. Categorical:
Chi-Square Test of Independence: Tests the association between two categorical variables. Fisher’s Exact Test: Alternative to Chi-Square Test, however, intended for smaller sample sizes.

title: Basics to Visualizations
text: Visualizing data is an essential part of the statistical process and plays a major role in Exploratory Data Analysis (EDA). By representing data visually, analysts and researchers can reveal patterns, trends, and relationships that may be hidden in raw numbers. Common visualization tools include histograms, bar charts, and scatter plots, each suited for different types of data and analyses. This document explores these graphs, their applications, and guidance on when to use them effectively.

title: Basics to Visualizations
text:
Histograms:
A histogram is a graphical representation that organizes a dataset into intervals or “bins.” Each bin represents a range of values, and its height corresponds to the number of observations within that range. Histograms are particularly useful for understanding the distribution of continuous data.

When to Use:
To assess the shape of the data distribution (e.g., normal, skewed, or uniform). To detect outliers or unusual data points. To identify multimodal distributions.


Example:
A histogram can be used to analyze the distribution of employee ages in a company. By visualizing age frequencies, patterns such as the concentration of younger employees or a diverse age range may emerge. Below is a created histogram for this scenario:

title: Basics to Visualizations
text:
Bar Charts:
A bar chart displays categorical data using rectangular bars. Each bar’s length represents the frequency or proportion of observations in a category. Unlike histograms, bar charts are used for discrete data and do not display intervals.

When to Use:
To compare counts or proportions across categories. To highlight differences between groups or segments. To visualize survey results or other categorical datasets.


Example:
A bar chart can illustrate the number of students in different academic programs, such as engineering, business, and arts. This visualization helps compare the popularity of each program. The resulting bar chart is provided below:

title: Basics to Visualizations
text:
Scatter Plots:
A scatter plot shows the relationship between two continuous variables. Each point represents an observation, with its position determined by the values of the two variables. Scatter plots are particularly effective for identifying correlations or patterns.

When to Use:
To explore the relationship or correlation between two variables. To detect clusters, trends, or outliers. To evaluate the strength and direction of a relationship.


Example:
A scatter plot can be used to analyze the relationship between marketing spend and sales revenue. A positive trend may suggest that increased marketing efforts lead to higher sales. An example of a scatterplot can be viewed below:

title: Basics to Visualizations
text:
Boxplots:
A boxplot is a graphical representation of the distribution of a dataset. It summarizes key statistics, including the median, quartiles, and potential outliers. The box represents the interquartile range (IQR), while the whiskers extend to the smallest and largest non-outlier values.

When to Use:
To visualize the spread and variability of data. To detect outliers in a dataset. To compare distributions across multiple groups.


Example:
A boxplot can be used to analyze the distribution of salaries in different job departments. By comparing salary distributions in IT, HR, Finance, and other departments, companies can assess pay disparities and variations within teams. A side-by-side boxplot of this scenario is shown below:

title: Basics to Visualizations
text:
Line Graphs:
A line graph effectively visualizes trends over time by connecting data points with a continuous line, making it easier to identify patterns, fluctuations, and long-term changes. While like a scatter plot, a line graph is particularly useful for highlighting trends and showing the progression of data over time. However, line graphs have a more specialized use and are most relevant in specific areas of statistical analysis, such as time-series data and trend forecasting.

When to Use:
To track changes over a period (e.g., daily, monthly, and yearly trends). To compare multiple trends in a single graph. To identify seasonal patterns or cyclical behavior.


Example:
A line graph can be used to analyze monthly sales revenue over a year. By plotting sales data for each month, businesses can identify peak seasons, declining trends, or the impact of marketing campaigns. Below is a line graph of our scenario:

title: Basics to Visualizations
text:
Choosing the Right Graph:
Selecting the appropriate graph depends on the nature of your data and the insights you want to gain:
Histograms – Best for understanding distributions and variability within a single dataset.
Bar Charts – Ideal for comparing counts or proportions across different categories.
Scatter Plots – Useful for evaluating relationships between two numerical variables.
Boxplots – Effective for visualizing data distributions, identifying outliers, and comparing variability across groups.
Line Graphs – Best suited for tracking trends over time and analyzing patterns in sequential data.
Graphs are essential for summarizing and communicating data effectively. By selecting the appropriate visualization—whether a histogram, bar chart, scatter plot, boxplot, line graph, or other relevant visual—you can reveal patterns, highlight trends, and support informed decision-making. Mastering these tools enhances clarity, accuracy, and the overall impact of statistical analyses, making data-driven insights more accessible and actionable.

title: Data Visualization: Best Practices and Pitfalls to Avoid
text:
Data visualization is a powerful tool that transforms raw data into meaningful insights. When done correctly, it enhances understanding, supports decision-making, and effectively communicates complex information. However, poorly designed visuals can mislead audiences, obscure key findings, and even distort the truth.
This guide outlines essential rules for creating clear, accurate, and impactful visualizations. These practices will help you craft compelling visuals that engage your audience and convey data with precision. Whether you’re a business analyst, researcher, or student, following these commonly used principles will ensure that your visual storytelling is both effective and ethical.

title: Data Visualization: Best Practices and Pitfalls to Avoid
text:
1. Know Your Audience
Before creating a visualization, consider who will view it and what they need to take away from it. A well-designed visualization should be clear, accessible, and suited to the audience’s level of expertise.
Understand Their Background
Are they data experts who can interpret complex charts, or will simpler visuals be more effective? Do they have prior knowledge of the topic, or will they need additional context to understand the data?
What Level of Detail Do They Need?
Are they looking for a quick summary of key insights, or do they need an in-depth breakdown of trends and relationships? Should your visualization highlight broad trends, or should it offer interactive elements for deeper exploration?
Consider the Presentation Format
Print (reports, posters): Ensure text is legible, colors are distinct, and the design is clear at different sizes. Digital (slides, dashboards, websites): Interactive elements, animations, and tooltips can make complex data easier to explore. Accessibility: Use colorblind-friendly patterns, readable fonts, and text descriptions for those using technology to follow along.
By tailoring your visualization to your audience’s needs and the format in which they will see it, you can make your data more effective and impactful.

title: Data Visualization: Best Practices and Pitfalls to Avoid
text:
2. Choose the Right Chart Type
Different types of data require different visualizations:
Bar Charts – Compare different categories easily Line Charts – Show trends over time Scatter Plots – Display relationships between variables Histograms – Understand the distribution of a dataset Stacked Bar Charts – Show part-to-whole relationships over time Maps – Best for geographic data
Specific examples of widely used charts can be found on our previous post, “Basics to Visualizations” on our Data Points Blog, which is linked here.
In general – Try to avoid pie charts when comparing multiple categories—bar charts are usually better!

title: Data Visualization: Best Practices and Pitfalls to Avoid
text:
3. Make It Easy to Read
A cluttered chart is a useless chart. Keep your design clean by:
Using clear labels and legends Keeping colors consistent and purposeful (Most visuals only use 3-5 colors!) Choosing legible font size Using Gridlines to help show differences
If people have to decode your chart instead of instantly understanding it, it’s not effective.
Here is an example of an easy-to-read graph:
Output image The graph features a clear title, gridlines, labeled axes, well-defined categories, and limits usage of color, ensuring viewers can easily understand the data and its interpretation.

title: Data Visualization: Best Practices and Pitfalls to Avoid
text:
4. Highlight Key Insights
Use color, bold text, or callouts to emphasize the most important takeaways. The goal isn’t just to show data—it’s to make the key message unmissable.
Example: Instead of just showing sales data, add a note saying, “Sales increased by 20% in Q4 due to a successful holiday campaign.”
Output image Building from point 3, point 4 emphasizes key insights using color, annotations, and callouts to make the most important takeaways stand out. However, it’s important to note that step 4 does not always need to be visually represented. Key findings can also be highlighted through textual analysis in a caption for a project or presentation. That said, visualizing these insights is a powerful way to enhance a project and improve audience understanding.

title: Data Visualization: Best Practices and Pitfalls to Avoid
text:
5. Ensure Data Accuracy
Misinformation spreads quickly, especially with bad visuals.
Always start your Y-axis at zero unless there’s a good reason not to. Use proportional scales to avoid distorting comparisons. Double-check numbers to avoid misleading insights.
By applying these practices to your work, you can create data visualizations that are not only visually appealing but also meaningful and effective. Clear, well-designed visuals ensure that your audience can quickly grasp key insights, make informed decisions, and trust the data being presented. When used correctly, data visualization becomes a powerful storytelling tool—turning raw numbers into impactful narratives.

title: Data Visualization: Best Practices and Pitfalls to Avoid
text:
1. Don’t Use Misleading Scales
A truncated Y-axis (one that doesn’t start at zero) can exaggerate trends, making small changes look dramatic.
Example: Look at these two side by side charts showing the same data:
Chart A (Misleading): Starts Y-axis at 50, making a small increase look huge. Chart B (Correct): Starts Y-axis at 0, showing a realistic growth pattern.
Output image Remember to always ensure your visuals represent the true scale of the data.

title: Data Visualization: Best Practices and Pitfalls to Avoid
text:
2. Don’t Overcomplicate Your Charts
Avoid 3D charts, excessive colors, or too many overlapping elements. Simplicity is key.
Bad: A pie chart with 10+ segments—nobody can compare them easily, even with proper labeling. Better: A bar chart with sorted categories for clarity.
Output image

title: Data Visualization: Best Practices and Pitfalls to Avoid
text:
3. Don’t Ignore Labels and Context
A graph without labels is like a story without words, so make sure to use label!
Bad: A scatter plot with no axis labels. Good: A clear title, labeled axes, and depending on it’s purpose, a short insight description.
Output image

title: Data Visualization: Best Practices and Pitfalls to Avoid
text:
4. Don’t Use Too Many Colors
Using a rainbow of colors may look exciting, but it often confuses readers.
Use a consistent color scheme (e.g., shades of blue throughout, red to highlight a key point).
Always Highlight important points with contrast, not chaos.
Output image

title: Data Visualization: Best Practices and Pitfalls to Avoid
section: 5. Don’t Forget to Verify Your Data
text:
5. Don’t Forget to Verify Your Data
Mistakes happen. Before publishing your visualization, ask yourself:
Are the numbers correct? Do the colors and labels make sense? Is the story accurate and unbiased?
Always remember – A great visualization is only as good as the data behind it.
At its core, data visualization is about telling a story. A great chart removes confusion, highlights key insights, and engages the audience.
By following these practices and avoiding common mistakes, you can create aesthetically pleasing and effective visuals—regardless of what field you find yourself in.
